original_definition: 'airborne acoustical noise emission' means the sound power level of a refrigerating appliance, expressed in A-weighted decibel referred to 1 pico watt (dB(A) re 1 pW);
generated_definition: 'airborne acoustical noise emission' means the level of noise emitted by an appliance through the air, as measured in decibels relative to a reference power of 1 watt (db(a))

Article 2: ‘low noise refrigerating appliance’ means a refrigerating appliance without vapour compression and withairborne acoustical noise emission lower than 27 A-weighted decibel referred to 1 pico watt (dB(A) re 1 pW);
‘airborne acoustical noise emission’ means the sound power level of arefrigerating appliance, expressed in A-weighted decibel referred to 1 pico watt (dB(A) re 1 pW);
‘airborne acoustical noise emission’ means the sound power level of a refrigerating appliance, expressed in A-weighted decibel referred to 1 pico watt (dB(A) re 1 pW);

‘low noise refrigerating appliance’ means a refrigerating appliance without vapour compression and with airborne acoustical noise emission lower than 27 A-weighted decibel referred to 1 pico watt (dB(A) re 1 pW);
Article 10: Low noise appliances are reported to have airborne acoustical noise emissions lower than 15 dB(A) re 1 pW according to current test standards.

At the time of entry into force of this Regulation, the best available technology on the market for refrigerating appliances in terms of their energy efficiency index (EEI) and airborne acoustical noise emissions was identified as outlined below.
